definitions: place too much weight or cargo on something causing strain
give someone more duties or obligations than they can reasonably handle
examples: The truck was overburdened with heavy construction materials
Don't overburden the shelves with too many books
The manager overburdened her team with unrealistic deadlines
Parents shouldn't overburden children with adult responsibilities

definitions: defeat an opponent or enemy in a struggle or conflict
affect someone very strongly with emotion making them unable to act normally
successfully deal with and get past a problem or difficult situation
examples: The army overcame fierce resistance from enemy forces
She overcame her opponent in the final match
He was overcome with grief when he heard the news
The audience was overcome by the beauty of the performance
They overcame poverty to build a successful business together
She overcame her fear of public speaking through practice

definitions: take a dangerously large amount of drugs or medication causing harm
consume or experience an excessive amount of something to the point of saturation
examples: The patient accidentally overdosed on sleeping pills last night
Many celebrities have overdosed on prescription painkillers tragically
I overdosed on reality TV shows during the weekend
The kids overdosed on candy during Halloween festivities

definitions: drive a vehicle or machine beyond its normal operating capacity causing strain
cause something to operate at maximum capacity or in an intensified state
examples: Don't overdrive the engine in cold weather conditions
He overdrove the rental car on mountain roads
The crisis put the emergency services into overdrive immediately
Her creative mind went into overdrive planning the event

definitions: calculate or judge something to be greater than its actual size or amount
think someone or something is better or more capable than they really are
examples: The contractor overestimated the cost of materials significantly
Scientists overestimated the storm's impact on coastal areas
Don't overestimate your ability to finish this project alone
Many people overestimate the importance of natural talent

definitions: flow over the edge or top of a container when too full
be so full that contents cannot be contained within normal limits
be filled with an intense emotion that cannot be contained or hidden
examples: The bathtub overflowed when she forgot to turn off the tap
Heavy rain caused the river to overflow its banks
The parking lot overflowed with cars during the concert
The hospital emergency room overflowed with injured patients
Her heart overflowed with gratitude for their kindness
The crowd overflowed with enthusiasm during the celebration

definitions: extend or project outward beyond something else below creating shade or shelter
remain as a threatening or worrying presence that affects current situations
examples: The cliff overhangs the beach by several meters dangerously
Tree branches overhang the garden path creating natural shade
The threat of war overhangs all diplomatic negotiations currently
Past mistakes still overhang his political career significantly

definitions: take apart and examine machinery or equipment thoroughly to repair or renovate it
examine and make major changes to a system or method to improve it significantly
examples: The mechanic will overhaul the engine next week completely
They overhauled the vintage aircraft to restore its functionality
The company plans to overhaul its management structure entirely
Congress voted to overhaul the healthcare system last year

definitions: hear a conversation or remark not intended for you without the speakers knowing
deliberately listen to others' private conversation without their knowledge or consent
examples: I overheard them discussing the surprise party yesterday accidentally
She overheard her name mentioned in the next room
The spy overheard classified information at the embassy reception
He deliberately overheard their business plans through the wall

definitions: become dangerously or uncomfortably hot beyond normal operating temperature
cause something to become too hot potentially causing damage or malfunction
examples: The laptop overheated after running for several hours continuously
The engine overheats when driving in heavy traffic
Don't overheat the oil when frying food at home
The faulty wiring overheated the electrical circuit causing problems

definitions: extend over something and cover part of it creating a shared area
occur at the same time as something else creating a scheduling conflict
have qualities or characteristics in common with something else creating similarity
examples: The roof tiles overlap to prevent rain from entering
The two circles overlap in the middle of the diagram
Our meetings overlap so I can't attend both today
The conference dates overlap with my vacation plans unfortunately
Their research interests overlap in several important areas significantly
The two departments' responsibilities overlap causing confusion sometimes

definitions: cover something with a layer of different material for protection or decoration
place or superimpose one thing on top of another especially in graphics or maps
examples: They will overlay the concrete with decorative tiles tomorrow
The artist overlaid gold leaf on the painting carefully
Overlay the current map with historical boundary data please
The designer overlaid text on the background image effectively

definitions: put too much electrical current or weight through a system causing failure
give someone more information or tasks than they can process effectively
examples: The surge overloaded the electrical circuit causing a blackout
Don't overload the washing machine with too many clothes
The complex instructions overloaded students with unnecessary details
Too many options can overload consumers making decisions difficult

definitions: fail to notice or consider something important due to lack of attention
have a view from above or from a higher position looking down
deliberately choose to ignore someone's fault or mistake without punishment
examples: The editor overlooked several spelling errors in the document
Don't overlook the small details in the contract
Our hotel room overlooks the beautiful Mediterranean Sea perfectly
The castle overlooks the entire valley from its position
The manager overlooked his tardiness because of his performance
I'll overlook your mistake this time but be careful

definitions: defeat or gain control over someone using superior strength or numbers
be so strong or intense that it completely dominates everything else present
examples: The security guards overpowered the intruder within seconds quickly
The larger army easily overpowered the defending forces
The smell of garlic overpowers all other flavors completely
Her perfume overpowered everyone in the small elevator

definitions: use one's authority to reject or cancel someone else's decision or order
interrupt an automatic function to take manual control of a system
examples: The president can override Congress with an executive order
The manager overrode my decision without consulting me first
Override the security system using the master code immediately
The pilot overrode the autopilot during severe turbulence

definitions: reject or disallow someone's decision using higher authority or power
officially decide against a legal objection or previous court decision
examples: The board overruled the committee's recommendation completely yesterday
The principal overruled the teacher's disciplinary action immediately
The judge overruled the defense attorney's objection quickly
The appeals court overruled the lower court's decision

definitions: invade and occupy a place quickly using military force or large numbers
continue beyond an intended time limit or scheduled ending point
spread over or throughout an area in large numbers causing problems
examples: Enemy forces overran the border defenses within hours
The rebels overran several government positions last night
The meeting overran by thirty minutes causing scheduling problems
The construction project overran its deadline by two months
Weeds have overrun the abandoned garden completely this summer
Rats overran the old warehouse making it uninhabitable

definitions: supervise and be responsible for work or workers ensuring proper completion
watch over and protect someone or something from a position of authority
examples: She oversees all marketing operations for the company globally
The foreman oversees construction workers on the building site
The committee oversees student welfare programs at the university
Government agencies oversee consumer protection laws and regulations

definitions: cast a shadow over something by blocking light from above
make someone or something seem less important by comparison with something greater
examples: Dark clouds overshadowed the mountain peak all day long
The tall buildings overshadow the historic church completely
His recent scandal overshadowed all his previous achievements unfortunately
The tragedy overshadowed what should have been a celebration

definitions: go past an intended stopping point or target accidentally while moving
exceed a planned amount or level going further than originally intended
examples: The plane overshot the runway during the emergency landing
The driver overshot the exit and had to turn around
The company overshot its sales target by twenty percent
Government spending overshot the budget by millions of dollars

definitions: move past another vehicle or person traveling in the same direction
become greater or more successful than someone or something previously ahead
come upon someone suddenly and strongly affecting their state or condition
examples: The sports car overtook three vehicles on the highway
Runners overtook him in the final lap of the race
China has overtaken Japan as the world's second economy
Digital sales overtook physical album sales last year significantly
Fear overtook her as she entered the dark basement
Sleep overtook him during the long boring lecture

definitions: remove a government or leader from power by force often through revolution
throw a ball beyond the intended target in sports missing the receiver
examples: Rebels attempted to overthrow the government last year unsuccessfully
The military overthrew the dictator in a sudden coup
The quarterback overthrew the receiver in the end zone
She overthrew first base allowing the runner to advance

definitions: turn something over so its bottom faces upward causing disruption
reverse a legal decision or ruling through higher authority or appeal
cause a vehicle or boat to turn over accidentally losing stability
examples: The earthquake overturned furniture throughout the entire house
Protesters overturned cars during the violent demonstration yesterday
The Supreme Court overturned the conviction on appeal recently
The new evidence overturned the original verdict completely
Strong winds overturned several boats in the harbor
The truck overturned on the icy road causing traffic

definitions: use something too much or too frequently causing problems or diminishing effectiveness
damage or wear out something through excessive use over time
examples: Many people overuse antibiotics for minor infections unnecessarily
Don't overuse that phrase or it loses its impact
Athletes often overuse certain muscles leading to injury
She overused her credit cards and accumulated massive debt

definitions: defeat someone or something completely through superior force or numbers
affect someone very strongly with emotion making them unable to cope
cover or bury something completely with a huge mass of something
examples: The invading army overwhelmed the city's defenses quickly
Superior numbers overwhelmed the small defending force entirely
Grief overwhelmed her when she received the tragic news
The kindness of strangers overwhelmed him with gratitude
The tsunami overwhelmed coastal villages within minutes tragically
Weeds have overwhelmed the neglected garden beds completely

definitions: survive through winter in a dormant state or with special adaptations
spend the winter season in a particular place usually warmer climate
examples: Many insects overwinter under tree bark for protection
These plants overwinter in the greenhouse until spring arrives
Monarch butterflies overwinter in Mexico every year remarkably
Many retirees overwinter in Florida escaping cold weather

definitions: work too hard or too long causing exhaustion or health problems
make someone or something work beyond reasonable limits causing strain
examples: She overworks herself trying to meet impossible deadlines constantly
Many employees overwork to prove their dedication unfortunately
Don't overwork the dough or it becomes tough
The manager overworks his staff during busy seasons regularly

definitions: have an obligation to pay money or return something to someone
have a moral obligation to give someone something in return for help
have something as a result of or thanks to a particular person or thing
examples: I owe the bank fifty thousand dollars for my loan
She owes me twenty dollars from last week's lunch
I owe you an apology for my rude behavior yesterday
We owe our parents everything for their sacrifices
He owes his success to years of hard work
The team owes their victory to excellent preparation

definitions: undergo or cause a chemical reaction combining with oxygen changing composition
become covered with rust through exposure to oxygen and moisture
examples: Iron oxidizes when exposed to air and moisture naturally
The copper statue oxidized creating a green patina
The metal surface oxidized after years of weathering
Silver jewelry oxidizes and becomes tarnished over time

definitions: walk back and forth in a small area usually because of anxiety or impatience
set or control the speed at which something happens or develops
measure a distance by walking with regular steps counting the number
examples: He paced nervously outside the hospital delivery room
The tiger paced restlessly in its cage all day
She carefully paced herself during the marathon race
The instructor paced the lesson to match students' abilities
He paced off the distance for the new garden bed
The surveyor paced the property boundaries before measuring

definitions: bring peace to an area by ending war or violence through force or negotiation
make someone who is angry or upset become calm and quiet
examples: The government sent troops to pacify the rebellious region
It took years to pacify the war-torn country completely
The mother pacified her crying baby with a bottle
His apology pacified the angry customer somewhat

definitions: put clothes and belongings into bags or boxes for traveling or storage
press or squeeze things tightly together into a confined space
carry or wear equipment and supplies especially for hiking or camping
examples: She packed her suitcase carefully for the business trip
We need to pack all our books before moving
Pack the snow firmly to make a good snowball
The crowd packed into the small concert venue tightly
Hikers pack enough supplies for three days outdoors
Soldiers pack heavy gear during training exercises daily

definitions: put something in a box or wrapping especially for sale or transport
present something in an attractive way to make it more appealing
examples: Workers package products in the factory assembly line daily
The company packages organic food in recyclable containers
Politicians package their message to appeal to voters
The publisher packaged the book series as a collector's edition

definitions: cover or fill something with soft material for protection or comfort
walk with quiet soft steps usually to avoid being heard
make something longer by adding unnecessary material to reach required length
examples: She padded the package with bubble wrap for shipping
They padded the chair seats for extra comfort
The cat padded silently across the wooden floor
He padded down the hallway in his socks
Students often pad their essays to meet word requirements
Don't pad the report with irrelevant information please

definitions: move a boat through water using a paddle or oar with repeated strokes
swim moving hands and feet in a simple dog-like motion
hit someone especially a child on the bottom as a form of punishment
examples: They paddled the canoe across the calm lake slowly
She paddles her kayak every weekend for exercise
Children paddle in the shallow end of the pool
The dog paddled frantically to reach the shore
Some schools used to paddle students for misbehavior
Parents rarely paddle their children anymore these days

definitions: fasten or secure something with a portable lock that hangs from a hasp
examples: He padlocked the shed to keep tools secure overnight
The owner padlocked the gate after closing time
They padlocked their bicycles to the metal rack securely
Workers padlocked the construction site for the weekend

definitions: call someone to come using a public address system or electronic device
turn through the pages of a book or document looking for something
examples: The hospital will page the doctor for emergencies immediately
Airlines page passengers who are late for boarding
She paged through the magazine during her lunch break
He paged through old photo albums looking for memories

definitions: cause physical discomfort or suffering to someone through injury or illness
cause mental or emotional suffering through worry or sadness
examples: My injured knee pains me when the weather changes
The wound still pains him despite taking medication
It pains me to see you so unhappy lately
The betrayal pained her more than she could express

definitions: cover a surface with paint to protect or decorate it
create a picture or artwork using paint as an artistic medium
describe something in a particular way using words to create mental image
examples: They painted the house blue to match the shutters
Workers paint the bridge every five years for protection
She paints landscapes in watercolors every weekend creatively
The artist painted her portrait in oils beautifully
The media painted him as a villain unfairly
The author paints a vivid picture of rural life

definitions: join or connect two things or people together for a purpose
put things together that complement or match each other well
form a romantic or working relationship with another person
examples: The teacher paired students for the science project randomly
Pair the socks before putting them in the drawer
The chef pairs wine with each course expertly
These colors pair well together in home decorating
The coach paired experienced players with newcomers deliberately
Birds pair up during the mating season naturally

definitions: lose color and become whiter usually from illness fear or shock
seem less important or impressive when compared to something else
examples: She paled when she heard the terrible news yesterday
His face paled at the sight of blood
Our problems pale compared to what they're facing
Local issues pale beside the global climate crisis

definitions: become boring or less interesting through being experienced too much
cover or spread over something like a dark cloud creating gloom
examples: The novelty of the game palled after several hours
Even luxury can pall when experienced daily
Smoke from the fire palled the entire valley
Dark clouds palled the sky before the storm

definitions: hide something in the palm of your hand using sleight of hand
get rid of something unwanted by tricking someone into taking it
examples: The magician palmed the coin during the trick smoothly
The thief palmed the jewelry while pretending to browse
He tried to palm off fake tickets to tourists
Don't let them palm inferior goods off on you

definitions: criticize something severely especially a performance or creative work publicly
move a camera horizontally to follow action or scan a scene
wash gravel in a pan to separate gold or precious metals
examples: Critics panned the movie for its poor acting completely
The reviewers panned his latest novel mercilessly
The cameraman panned across the beautiful landscape slowly
Pan the camera to follow the action smoothly
Prospectors panned for gold in the mountain streams
They spent summers panning for gold in Alaska

definitions: do or provide what someone wants even though it may be wrong or harmful
act as a go-between in sexual or immoral dealings for profit
examples: Politicians often pander to voters' fears during elections
The media panders to public appetite for scandal
He was accused of pandering to criminal elements
The establishment was shut down for pandering illegally

definitions: cover or decorate a wall or surface with flat rectangular sections
serve as a member of a committee or group making decisions
examples: They paneled the library walls with dark oak beautifully
The contractor will panel the basement next week
She panels regularly for academic conference reviews
Experts panel to discuss climate change solutions monthly

definitions: ask strangers for money in public places as a way of living
examples: He panhandles outside the subway station every morning
People panhandle more frequently during economic downturns unfortunately
She was arrested for panhandling in the business district
Many cities have laws against panhandling aggressively

definitions: feel or show sudden uncontrollable fear or anxiety losing rational control
cause someone to feel sudden overwhelming fear making them act irrationally
examples: She panicked when she couldn't find her passport
Investors panicked and sold their stocks hastily yesterday
Don't panic the horses with sudden movements please
The fire alarm panicked everyone in the building

definitions: breathe with short quick breaths typically from exertion or excitement
have an intense desire or longing for something or someone
examples: The dog panted heavily after chasing the ball repeatedly
She panted from climbing the steep stairs quickly
The young artist panted for recognition and fame desperately
He panted after wealth his entire adult life
